awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Macrophysiological patterns in the thermal and optical properties of ant cuticular structures
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Broadening Participation of Groups Underrepresented in Biology. The Fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The project seeks to understand the connection between the structure of ant hairs and cuticles and their thermal and optical properties in variable environmental conditions. Variation in the thermal properties of ant cuticles and hairs may allow them to heat up in cool environments and stay cool in hot environments. Patterns in thermal and optical properties will be analyzed across species along an elevational gradient in the Chiricahua Mountains in Arizona, and within species across latitudinal gradients in North America (from Canada to Mexico). As the first survey of biodiversity in cuticular structures with unique thermal/optical properties, this project will inspire engineering applications for global thermal and energy challenges (solar energy capture, radiative cooling, biomimetic materials, etc.). The Fellow will also develop curricular materials about thermal properties of living organisms to be used in high-need Los Angeles schools and published in peer-reviewed education journals as well as hosting culturally responsive mentoring and grant writing workshops for minoritized students at the host institutions and national conferences.

The Fellow will use scanning electron microscopy to analyze the microstructure of ant cuticles and hairs, using both existing museum collections of widespread North American ant species and specimens collected by the Fellow along an elevational gradient at the Southwestern Research Station in Arizona. Fourier-transform infrared thermography, reflectance spectrophotometry (from ultraviolet to mid-infrared), and finite element method modeling will be used to analyze the thermal and optical properties of ant cuticular structures. Environmental data collected using local weather stations will be used to understand if solar radiation and temperature can predict the optical/thermal properties of ant cuticular structures. The research is integrated with an education plan aimed at increasing participation of underrepresented groups by 1) developing K-12 lesson plans in partnership with Noyce Scholars and Master Teacher Fellows to be used in high-need Los Angeles schools, and 2) publishing these plans in peer-reviewed and open access education journals. In addition, the Fellow will expand culturally responsive mentoring programs for minoritized postdocs and students at California State University Dominguez Hills and University of Southern California.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to understand how biological organisms adapt to the thermal challenge posed by heat from sunlight across large scale geographic gradients. We studied this in ants and birds, looking at the reflectance of their external surfaces as a way to understand how they absorb or reflect light/heat from the sun in the visible and near infrared.

A paper is now in progress on the NIR and MIR reflectance of five species of birds across latitudinal gradients; these results suggest that, in some species, reflectance profiles change intraspecifically in relation to climate conditions. Further, data collection is in progress from two other initiatives: 1) collection of ants that were obtained from nine sites across an elevation gradient in the Chiracahuas; and 2) museum specimens of closely related diurnal-nocturnal insect pairs from the Melbourne Museum. These studies all relate to the projects' main goal of understanding how solar radiation impacts the optical and thermal properties of biological organisms.

Training and broader impact objectives that were met included ant collection and identification, optical imaging, and spectrometry, as well as professional development including presentations/workshop development, job materials for tenure-track faculty positions, culturally responsive mentoring opportunities, and developing tools for diversifying higher education. Three undergraduate students were mentored at CSUDH, one graduate student was mentored in the field at ASU, and one MS student in engineering, interested in birds and beetle cuticular reflectance, was mentored at UCLA.

During this fellowship period, a virtual networking workshop and a grant-writing workshop were organized in collaboration with EntoPOC (a group that promotes the participation of people of color in Entomology) at the International Union for the Study of Social Insects meeting. Further, I ran a bi-weekly virtual grant writing space for students that attended that workshop in the fall, as well as a weekly virtual publication-writing space for graduate students. At CSUDH, I developed ran three professional development workshops on Research Ethics and Research and Writing Skills. I hosted a talk for faculty at CSUDH about how to find and support postdoctoral scholars, in order to bring more postdocs to PUIs that support primarily minoritized students.

I also have initiated planning for a CSU-wide postdoctoral network, in order to better support the postdoctoral scholars in our system. Many of these institutions are not research-heavy, and so postdocs are few and far between; the network I worked to start will assist postdocs in developing connections, finding resources, and getting peer-support while working at a CSU. This is directly aiming to increase diversity at the postdoctoral level in the CSU system and support underrepresented students from the CSUs in having access to early career mentors in STEM.
